Subject: Warning: Capping the maximum and minimum link weight may be important!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

It has come to my attention that in the publicly available version of
NEAT that most people have been working off of, there is no maximum
link weight, i.e. link weights can grow unbounded.

This is not necessarily terrible but I wanted to make sure people
realized that from most of my experience, having a cap of some sort
*is* desirable.  Ideally the cap would be related to the
weight_mut_power in some way, such that there is room for several
weight mutations in either direction.  

For example, if the max linkweight is 3 and the min is -3, then the
weight_mut_power might make sense at about 0.5, so that there is room
for several increments or decrements in that range.  

Here is some code to insert at the end of mutate_link_weights to cause
there to be a cap:

//Cap the weights at 3.0 (experimental)
if (((*curgene)->lnk)->weight>3.0) 
     ((*curgene)->lnk)->weight=3.0;
else if (((*curgene)->lnk)->weight<-3.0)
     ((*curgene)->lnk)->weight=3.0;

I encourage anyone who is running more than a few hundred generations
to install a cap like this.  That way, your link weights cannot become
eventually so powerful that they overshadow the weights of any new
links that might appear.  This may help a lot in some people's
experiments that are going for thousands of generations or more.

ken
